header.title: The Golden Fleece: A Book of Jewish Cabalism

central_thesis: The central thesis is that a universal, immutable 'Hebraic law' underlies all languages, nature, and human history, accessible through a specific method of 'double reading' and interpretation of letters, words, and myths. This law reveals God's dealings with man, the cyclical nature of life, death, and spiritual transformation, and is embedded in everything from pagan mythology to biblical narratives and astronomical patterns. The 'Golden Fleece' itself symbolizes this profound, hidden knowledge and the method to attain it.

structure_content.summary: Introduces the concept of 'face and reface' in reading language, where the superficial meaning ('face') is for practical affairs, while the deeper 'reface' reveals the universal 'Hebraic law.' This law connects all names in pagan mythology and provides a method for interpreting ancient sculpture, asserting its timeless and constant nature.

Details the method of extracting Hebrew from any language. Every letter and utterance holds a deeper, divine meaning beyond its common use. The process involves treating letters as syllables, adding specific vowels (H, E, A, V, Y) to each, doubling V, and positioning Y with A and I. U is a 'clean letter' used to form 'Y, O, U,' symbolizing the urn and gateway to immortality. Words are broken down by letters and syllables, exploring 'conceivable possible displacement,' with emphasis on the 'oh (O)' and 'ah (R)' sounds, linked to the 'sculler of Golgotha.' The chapter also provides rules for manipulating letters (adding/subtracting H, sticks, crooks, I) to uncover hidden words and meaning, emphasizing the 'harmonious blending of all dialects' as the Hebraic law.

Expands on the cabalistic interpretation of letters, linking them to a seven-day cycle of creation/life. Each letter from H to G (1-7) represents fundamental concepts (e.g., E with A for death, H uniting with A for octaves). It presents Fig. 2 as a diagram of this law, showing man's life as a 7-year cycle. The author reiterates that analyzing language reveals a deeper divine law, connecting pagan mythology and ancient Jewish interpretations.

Begins with the biblical phrase 'In the beginning was the word, and the word was with God, and the word was God,' setting a foundation for the divine nature of language. It introduces numerical correspondences (e.g., 6+2+1=9, representing 'the cat,' which 'reads, see sun and cross = eye'). The chapter correlates the musical minor scale to figures and associates specific numbers with the five senses, linking them to bodily and spiritual existence. An 'Astrological Dial' (Page 17) maps letters A-L to months (March-February) and numbers (1-12), revealing time-based laws, death, and the 'fruit of the tree of knowledge of good and evil' within this framework.

Presents a direct list of numerical correspondences (1-11) to divine and cosmic concepts such as 'God,' 'Unity,' 'Trinity,' 'Death,' 'Lord,' 'Virgin,' 'Holy,' 'Temple,' and 'Kat.' It then links numerical sums (e.g., 1+0=Globe=O,I,A; 1+1=Unity=2=B) to these concepts, emphasizing the interconnectedness of all things. A subsequent list assigns esoteric meanings to letters A-K (e.g., A=Sun rise, B=Earth, C=Cut life/vision, D=Bodily death, E=Law, F=Fan, G=Foundation, H=Temple/A opened, I=Eye, J=Janus, K=Key).

This chapter connects the 'Voyage of Jason' to zodiacal and human life cycles, starting with Pisces (12th month, 'ash death') and the symbol Y (urn). It delineates the astrological signs' influences, where specific months (e.g., F sets against February) correspond to different aspects of soul and body 'readjustment' within the 'womb of the zodiac.' The 'X crosses' (Fig. 4) symbolize deaths. The 'wheel of fortune' and 'circular dell' represent the foundation of man's syllables and the temple of nature, with the 'cereals of Virgo' being a 'panacea' or 'God's temple of time and its divisions.'

Analyzes the letter A as composed of three sticks, representing the sun and half of the daily light circle (east, noon, west). Fig. 6 shows how a circle within a double A symbolizes the earth, and a dividing line creates 'two DDs' (light/darkness), where A becomes D=O. The chapter elaborates on the esoteric meaning of 'DDs,' linking them to east/west, doves, turtle doves, bullocks, and pigeons. It describes the 'bidlock' (Fig. 7) formed by four Ds, and shows how the symbols represent core elements of the 'Hebraic law.'

Focuses on the letter E, which when written in full, comprises four sticks of equal length, forming a square plat (when a cross-piece is added), signifying the 'fifth' letter, 'the law,' and 'the fifth house of the year – July (Lion).' It connects E to 'Eli, Eloi, heloi, helais, Elias,' defining Elias as 'alias' or 'he of many names.' The chapter illustrates how 'squaring the E' and placing O inside combines to form 'Lord God,' and numerical sums (5+15=20) yield T, the 'cross.' It further explains that removing parts of E reveals F, symbolizing 'A' and 'A'.

Explores the letter H as three equal sticks, the 'silent 8th letter,' completing one octave and starting the next by uniting with A, thus completing the gamut. Fig. 8 illustrates how H can become A through 'swinging the sticks together.' This chapter explicitly links H to 'the gallows upon which Haman was hung,' detailing Haman's 'ash death' at age 49 and his soul's journey through 'sheol, hades, and hell' before returning to life as the 'twins Castor and Pollux' (Ahasuerus and Mordecai). It connects various astronomical events (Aries 20th, Cancer 24th, Libra 20th) to morning, noon, and night, and explains that Fig. 8b is 'older than the pyramids,' representing fundamental suffering at 'Golgotha.'

Analyzes the letter I as the '9th letter' (3x3), representing the 'all seeing eye of Almighty God,' and on a lower scale, the 'sun.' J, the '10th letter,' symbolizes the 'outstretched arm of the Almighty' and is formed by two sticks at a 120-degree angle with stones. J is identified with 'JEHOVAH-JIREH,' signifying the 'time of an advent' and the altar of Isaac and the Ram. The chapter explains how Isaac, slain in Arez, takes the name of the lamb, and Orion (the Ram) slays the bull, passing through 12 zodiacal signs. It posits that biblical characters like Adam, Abraham, Moses, David, and Jason represent different facets of this continuous, transfigurative journey influenced by the changing 'astronomical characters' of the alphabet, with each name adapting to the 'sign aspect of the heavens.'

Examines the letter K as the '11th letter,' constructed from three sticks and originating from the 'Styx.' It links K to 'ka kay kee ke key' in Hebrew and to the 'kiss of Judas' (K with eye and serpent S), symbolizing betrayal by 'double time (life).' K is shown to be changeable to R (a six-pointed star) and blends with A in 'seek.' The chapter describes the alphabet as a continuous 'wheel within a wheel,' where numbers gather from 11 to 1 and 25 to 1. Fig. 10 illustrates K in its full form as a 'sad iron, goose, and flat iron,' with a 'hole punched' to represent divisibility. This hole, or 'wafer hole,' is the 'death of the sun man' and the 'key to the bottomless pit,' connecting to archangel Mercury and all material and real aspects of existence.

Focuses on the letter L as the '12th letter,' signifying 'death' and connecting to 'Pisces,' the 'foot and last of the year.' It explains that L is formed by two sticks at a right angle (Fig. 11), which can also represent 'eight' (LL) or 'ninety' (L+O) or other divisions of time found in biblical stories. The chapter provides a series of symbolic images derived from this letter, such as 'Pigeons,' 'Bullock,' 'Turtle,' 'He Goat,' 'She Goat,' 'Kidneys,' 'Flanks,' 'Caul,' 'Last,' 'Kid,' and 'Ashes,' all embodying different aspects of death, transformation, and physical anatomy within the cabalistic framework.

Discusses the northern heavens as the origin of the 'law of language' and human redemption. It links Adam's fall and subsequent divine intervention (spirit in neck) to the 'cruise of Jason,' a recurring 2000-year event. The polar star, small dipper, and Ursa Minor are identified as 'the bar.' The letter P (16th letter) is explored as the arc of heaven, connecting to Ursa Minor and Major ('Father and Son') and the unity of divine law. It defines 'minor' as the sixth of the scale (La), the letter F, the number of Virgo, and the sixth of the week ('fry day'), symbolizing the serpent and 'time and repent,' where the northern pole serves as the starting point of divine revelation.

Interprets the 'shepherd's crook' as a 'half circle' and 'bail.' By placing it on P, it forms B, representing the 'yoke of Ulysses' and 'July sees.' Two crooks form 'two BBs' or 'two PPs.' The chapter delves into the symbolism of cutting D in two to slay the dragon, linking it to 'beating the devil.' It connects the 'son's crook' to forming 'cub' (O) by placing it on P. The 'BBs' tied into O become 'SHEOVAH and SHEVAH,' explaining the slaying of the dragon as the 'cruise I fix on.' The statue of Mercury is described as holding two balls, a string, a magic wand, and a scroll, all symbolizing his 'double nature' as the twin 'Castor and Pollux,' who brings life to the body and controls vocal organs, explaining healing and 'lunar' time cycles.

Analyzes the phrase 'San T laws' (Santa Claus, San T claws), linking it to the 'pun ish' persecution of Jews. 'Elijah's journey into Pyrrhic fire' is linked to the mantle (Gemini) and Elisha, representing Castor and Pollux. The 'hub of the arc' is the axle and spokes, the 'felloes' are the 12 zodiacal segments, and 'Orion' is the tire, brazed at 'Tekel' (Pisces and Aries). The fire in the center ('hub') is the nut, seed, and germ of life, distinguishing it from 'wheel' or 'fire worship' by focusing on God's power. Figures like Hiram of Tyre and Peter are identified as 'Master' and 'rock' of the church, connecting to the concept of 'Tyre' as 'tire' or 'downward plumb.'

Focuses on the letter Q, which follows P (P shot into F), with its tail representing a new 'circle of life' from O. It describes a spiritual journey where the soul is 'hung' in 'H air,' gaining foresight ('back hair=cue'). The 'fine hairy gaseous threads of the Holy Ghost' are considered the 'invisible power of God.' R symbolizes the 'serpent' and a 'broken spine,' with the 'pin in the tail' being the 'pen' or 'club of Hercules.' The chapter explains R as equivalent to P (a monogram) and the title of a being with 'three names' enduring intense purification. It breaks down the sound and meaning of R ('are, ha, ah, iar, ari, air') and the letter S as a 'circle' or two 'half circles twisted' into an 'ogee,' signifying the 'serpent, time, and the track on which the house of God moves.'

Explores the 'fall of the year and of man' as 'autumn' (awe tom), linking it to the 'mathematics' of the soul and the 'mysteries' revealed when 'finger of time points to the holes in the hands feet and side.' It connects these physical points to 'ash death' at Pisces and Arez (30th day) and suffering in Gemini. The five holes in the Jewish alphabet are identified as 'the weasel,' representing 'four corners and the center.' The chapter refers to Thomas's disbelief and the need for 'hope in faith.' God's utterance 'you (U)' to all creation, through 'D,' becomes 'youd, chewed, Jewed.' It also decodes 'W' as 'double U' and its numerical values (4Vs, 8Vs) as the 'sign of Aquarius – Jove – Janus.'

Identifies 'April' with the 'X crosses,' symbolizing sufferings between TTTs, V, and Ys. It explains the 'bar' on T as the 'revolution of the zodiac,' causing deaths to vary by season. Names also change with generations, obscuring history for those 'looking backward.' The chapter links '6+4=10' to O and the 'key,' showing how the soul ascends to the 'upper strata' or 'third heaven' via T and X. It connects 'Mount Olives' to 'live R (liver)' and 'Prometheus chained to Mount Caucasus' to the soul's trials (7x7=49 years). The result of a year's trials is '13 suspensions of animation, 3 of which were deaths,' leading to a 'spiritual birth' adjusted to the 'polar line' of the 'circumpolar heavens.'

Places 'nineteen centuries of time' onto the first 19 letters of the Roman alphabet, asserting that syllables and their connections reveal world history. The 'inward man' is constructed on a 19-law related to 'digestive organs,' with terms like 'rector,' 'wreck torn,' and 'rectum' linked to the end of digestion and the law. W (4 sticks, two right angles) and V (right angle) are discussed. The chapter predicts the 'sphyncter and sphynx of time' will be reached by 1901 (letter T), and explains 'Pan monogram' (P with T) as building with D and three sticks. It connects 'DIT, DIX' to 'puny, punny, puerile way,' and 'juvenile' to 'Jew Nile' and 'Babylon,' ultimately linking the 'Carthagenian language' to 'Punic' as 'the strongest.'

States that 'Mercury' arrives on earth in the '1886th year,' calculated from the 'double A' and the 'cross at the apex.' The body designated to receive this spirit is born under 'Virgin' (12th day, representing death), with 13 symbolizing 'death unto a new life by the sun,' creating a balance between life and death. The 'wood type' of this birth is 'poplar,' and the 'second life' is 'elm,' where 'square M' equals '13 the sun.' The chapter concludes that 'poplar' contains 'P' and 'polar,' further integrating linguistic and symbolic meanings into the narrative of reincarnation and divine cycles.

Describes 'Mercury' piercing the 'Easter-egg,' where the earth is the yolk and the air is the white. This event is numerically linked to '86' (14=N) and '87' (15=O), leaving '13 years' (M) on the A and S century. Calculations (86+87=173=01 73 / O D) are presented. The year '1901' is identified as when the 'firmament commences to cross the serpentine orbit' (Fig. 12 and 14). The entire system of time divisions is hung in the center and swings on the figure '8,' embodying the 'law Hebraic.' The year '1888' is termed 'year one' by Roman indication, where '8 appears three times.' The chapter illustrates how the 'firmament' turns on its axis and crosswise, unifying mathematical laws within the serpentine orbit.

Declares that 'every syllable in language has 4 meanings,' interconnected by internal resemblances and blending 'earthly' and 'heavenly' meanings. Only 'two meanings' are discernible on earth. The 'ish of the Jew' is seen in 'his,' while 'describe' is linked to 'scribe after death' and 'time crib and weasel.' The foundation of language is to sound every letter with 'seven vowels,' progressing through 25 letters by 'law of chances in displacement,' reaching a 'quadrature in sounds.' Upon leaving the body, the soul perceives '4 meanings' in all circumstances and the '4 quarters of the heavens.' The chapter explains 'read B' as 'bread from heaven' and the 'law of four' for lunar cycles (4x7=28=O days), with an added day for the 'last octave' (29 days), reflecting the 'physical construction of both sexes.'

Interprets 'Hades' through phonetic breakdowns like 'hay tis,' 'hat is,' and 'H eye tis,' linking it to 'hight is' and 'height is,' where '8 is' and 'ate is the fruit of the tree,' signifying the soul's march. It states that earthly words are 'stumbling-blocks' to the soul, which must 'Hebrew the whole' to become a 'spirit perfect.' The simplicity of this cabalistic work is astonishing once the meaning of syllables is applied to the soul's post-mortem journey. The word 'said' becomes 'sad' due to the 'eye (I) on the soul,' and 'meant' becomes 'ment' as the soul is in. Fig. 15, 'Gallows on which Haman was hung,' symbolizes these concepts of spiritual passage.

Connects 'Pan' to being a pagan 2000 years ago, highlighting the Romans' ignorance of this knowledge. It identifies the 'carpenter' or 'chariot painter of Aleppo' as a 'black man,' whose fate was sealed by 'God hardening hearts.' The chapter asserts that the '12 gods of 8000 years ago,' the '12 tribes of Israel,' '12 sons of Jacob,' '12 gods of Greece,' '3 and 9 muses of the Egyptians,' and '12 apostles' all represent the same divine law, stating that 'Paganism was, and is, Christism and Christianity.' It explains that when a man is born into a race, they become the 'Jews' for 2000 years, while others are 'Gentiles.' Figures like Abraham (Bramah) and Lincoln are mentioned as being 'put upon the altar,' and the 'missing link' of L in C oh L N is revealed, defining 'colon' as 'two dots = D ots,' symbolizing the 'foot of God.'

Elaborates on the 'sun man's' suffering through all signs (moon south to polar star north), caught in 'eight times the cube of 25 letters.' This forms the '4 quarters of the heavens.' The sun man takes the name 'Elias' (alias) and all earthly names fit him. Catastrophes, triumphs, and 'hair-breadth escapes' are consequences of his suffering. 'The death of Ham' is linked to 'deadham – Dedham,' and bridge disasters to the 'leap from heaven.' Names like Bradford bridge, Aquari, and engine-driver (death river) are imbued with symbolic meaning. The 'Ashtabula bridge disaster' is a 'forewarning' of 'war N in G.' The 'turnover of Q (D)' is the history of Dover and Andover. Finally, '4 fires in New Hampshire' (Suncook, Lebanon, New Boston, Newton Junction) symbolize the 'junction with heaven earth and hell.'

Explores 'Aquarius and Pisces' as the 'low quarter of man,' where Peter sank in the 'lye ford of C' and Mercury entered his neck, triumphing over 'ash death.' The 'sun closed the circle' of life. 'Gar' means 'voice in the throat' and is 'tar.' The 'garter on the leg' signifies the 'depth of sin K (sink) of Peter,' and 'sink' is 'S in K' or 'time in key.' The tale of Peter is connected to the '12th bin of the zodiac' (Pisces) and the need for a new 'name story' for all months and divisions of the year (3, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 20). Fig. 7's globes symbolize 'bears and bars,' the cross represents 'successful crossing of orbits,' and the anatomy of bears (suck claws) embodies 'see laws,' with a 'globe' being a verb of constant motion.

Posits that the 'ark (arc) of the tabernacle of God' is the course of A from east to west (Fig. 17). Only 'one person entered this at a time,' kneeling south and praying for mercy. The syllable 'tude' (duet/dute) is 'chewed' with H as 'thude' in the soul's course, and 'longitude' means 'long I chewed' (L on G I chewed), representing the plumb line from pole to arctic center, with latitude as the cross (D you wet). The 'displacement of 25 letters' reveals the law governing man's daily rounds and his inability to grasp interconnectedness. The author criticizes man's intellectual pride, his 'piling up thousands of volumes of theology,' and his failure to understand the 'rod of iron' (God's rule) and the 'gigantic joke' of existence.

Reveals the 'death and transfiguration of Hercules' as depicted in ancient statuary, likening the 'Assyrians' stripping a man's skin to 'war captives,' indicating that men of this age might misinterpret past events. The chapter defines the soul in the body as 'malt' and purgatory as a 'distillery,' where the 'undeveloped spirit' is held captive by fleshly beliefs. It argues that man's 'preconceived ideas' based on 'moon's influence' make him irritable to opposition, leading to the worship of 'images of their own imagination.' The moon's 30-day cycle limits human understanding. The suffering in this epoch is readable through the 'double' and corresponds to the 'sun man's experience.' King Herod is the 'rod of the Virgin,' meaning the 'Angel of the Lord,' whose column of 'od figures' (D in Fig. 3) reveals the 'slaying of the first born' as the discovery of history's repeat.

Explains that terms like 'Griffin, unicorn, sea-serpent, mermaid, lion with a man's head' all represent the same 'Pyrrhic traveller' (Callisto). It states that all life forms undergo periodic rebirths (restorers), a repetition of the original creation forces. The chapter discusses how 'hard sluggers' must learn the 'double reed,' linking 'ant, nat, tan' to 'T is N.' It asserts that the 'heavenly sheet of signs' governs articulation, leading to 'slang phrases.' Language subtly changes over time, yet Hebrew remains constant, based on astrological law. The text notes that older biblical words are obscure due to 'changing aspect of the heavens,' and fiery letters burn the law, representing 'the ax and acts' at the 'present edge of time.'

Emphasizes that names, dates, and numbers reveal the signs of the current epoch, though man cannot fully unravel the 'combination' in the flesh. The 'unison of language' reveals God's unalterable law. The 'double reading' is equated with the 'sign of Jonah,' symbolizing recurrent, timeless truth, like the 'double hautboy of Pan.' The 'fig-tree' represents how Romans built their alphabetical law, which they later lost. The 'cursing of that fig-tree' is parallel to the 'cessation of work on the Tower of Babel,' whose language was 'confounded.' The 'P roof' of the 'double read' is the 'eat in G' of music. The chapter concludes with Fig. 18, depicting two hawk-feathers that illustrate the 'eater piece of time,' representing the difference between the '8x8 square' and the '5x13 oblong square.'

Explains that the 'yellow seedy flower' represents the cabalistic meaning in biblical comparisons, with 'stone' linked to 'bread' ('t one,' 'D bear'). The 'T M' signifies 'two and four sticks' (2x4=8, the temple). The chapter asserts that the 'law' (square, sun, LL=storks) and its parts (flanks, lapwing) always give perfect names. It connects 'three TTTs of Golgotha' to divine love and suffering, viewing this as God's will. The author critiques man's inability to comprehend this, leading to 'contemplation' and 'rest' instead of understanding. The 'law of the circle of life,' though broken between Pisces and Aries, governs all life and is tied to the sun and the 'owl family.' The letter 'E' becomes 'I' via the 'four-sided square with a dot,' symbolizing the 'weasel,' and ultimately the painter's easel and the cross's right angles.

Describes esoteric creatures like the 'Griffin,' 'unicorn,' and 'rattlesnake' as symbolic representations of man's 'Pyrrhic traveller' experience, containing 'the warning of the goat (December)' at the tail and 'fangs of Aquarius (January)' at the head. The chapter relates 'a cycle of 2000 years' to the 'rattle' at the '20th century,' and connects the 'slight warning' (S=hiss) to the 'fly in Egypt' and the 'blowing of the horn' at the 19th century. It asserts that 'giants' in those days were much larger bodies than souls. The Bible is a condensed work where all words are 'abbreviations' that read 'four ways' and connect through a circle ('tyre'). The chapter also mentions 'ticks' and 'tactics of military,' linking them to 'up Tom from hard D' and 'up Tom from H,' to find 'gold' as 'old G' and 'bdellium' as 'on X stone.' It concludes that all 'time stories' in the King James Bible mean 'seven with the eighth added for one.'

Explains that 'one jot or one tittle' of God's law never changes. The 'geometrical way' of 'shifting back and fourth' between 'cubes' and 'balls' expresses 'vibrations in nature.' The chapter critiques 'earthly mathematicians' who believe good conduct leads directly to heaven, asserting that in 'purgatory' souls become 'infants' crying to the 'Holy Mother.' Souls plunged into 'sheol' must shed earthly knowledge to enter the 'kingdom of even' (O). Man's hope for faith relies on a 'hope line,' but 'punishment is swift and sure' for misdeeds. Theological disputes are 'never-ending.' The soul's 'cruise of purgatory' leads to spiritual life, guided by God's voice. The 'law of larvae' describes dormant souls. The chapter condemns man's 'dishonest dealings,' emphasizing that every act is 'seen, known, and on record' and will be accounted for.

Argues that 'God directly' and with 'unfailing surety' provides immortality through knowledge of 'heavenly realities.' However, man's blind reliance on leaders and errors obscures this truth. The 'onion' is worshipped, and its 'doubled life' revealed through 'parsnip, turnip, beet.' The 'arrow MA' (aroma) symbolizes unseen power, with 'hawk eye' representing 'nine.' The chapter asserts that people of this epoch, like those in Jonah's time, struggle to believe in spirit as matter, clinging to physical understanding. It states that God forbids man from seeing divine events directly, instead embedding them in natural law and the 'square cross.' The 'mesh of M ish' represents the 'basket where the soul basks,' and figures like '46800' signify 'ate and two circles = lives.' The chapter concludes that 'the soul is readjusted' after death, leaving suffering 'squares' to be 'born again.'

Explains that the 'Hebraic law' is connected to 'heaven, earth, and hell' and revealed through prophetic warnings ('this L fish will swallow every soul'). 'E is sun in Leo' and 'A is sun in Aries,' and 'U is the air,' forming the 'E A U' of dialect (the 'hole and entrance to God'). The chapter criticizes man's constant search for 'chaos' as proof of God, arguing that God's works are proofs of his existence. It states that man's 'instinctive imagination' distorts his understanding of the future, leading to disbelief. To understand, one must 'mix with the grace of God and see 50 a P.' It describes the 'black race' as the 'Jews for the past 2000 years,' and asserts that 'Pan is meant, fan is meant, han,' connecting linguistic puns to deeper racial and historical meanings.

Interprets 'self-ish' as 'elfish' or 'hell fish,' linking it to Jonah. The chapter claims 'L fish will swallow every soul,' and 'E is sun in Leo' connects to 'EAU' for 'hole and entrance to God.' Man's constant search for 'chaos' is depicted as a misunderstanding of God's works. The text states that 'the bowman of no V ember shoots across the dell' and identifies 'Phillip' as the 'November apostle' and 'sun man – Samson.' The body is described as having 'no V ember,' while the soul receives 'embers' (longitude/latitude of the mesh). The 'cheek of the jaw' is 'chop,' and 'Cheops,' revealing the 'jaw of the ass.' Adam's rib is the 'system he was married to,' and 'style' (O) is 'lye the mash' (M ash), tying anatomy and language to divine law.

Connects 'Rameses' to the 'Ram' and 'Sennacherib.' 'G all on' forms 'gallon,' composed of '4 quarts' (Pison, Gihon, Hiddekel, Euphrates). 'Havilah' signifies the 'circle around the whole' and the 'neck,' linked to 'havalock.' 'The goat – Pan' is tied to 'Mene Mene Tekel Upharsin' ('you pass in – to sheol – the O'). The chapter describes the soul's journey through 'purgatory and hell' and its arrival in the 'land of fire' (seven churches of Asia, spiritual Paraisians). 'The boils of Job' are equated with 'overflowing in mead.' The word 'dynasty' means 'ash death' and a 'period of 2000 years' ('war in heaven'). The 'atlas of the heavens' illustrates the 'sun man's' experience through 24 months, and 'mythology tales' relate to ancient stories. 'Esau's head of hair' and 'apostle' are linked to 'V airy' and the 'post,' with 'E with L' signifying 'surety.'

Declares that 'all souls will be Thomases after death,' experiencing a reality beyond earthly belief. 'All are Peters, and Judases,' sustaining these roles in 'sheol,' seeing the 'sun in Alpha and Aleph the bull' (Alpha becomes Aleph). 'Introduce' is linked to 'Duced in the T roe' (Duce=double nature, suffering), and 'menu' (fruit of tree) is tied to the eating of the forbidden fruit, where M is N and U is the Holy Ghost. The chapter explains that all names (like 'Adam') reveal life events. The 'rib of Adam' and 'pan creas' are connected to the 'spear and left (lee F T) side.' 'Pancreas' is Pan and Ceres (Virgin). The 'so-called nails' are 'Egyptian feathers,' representing the 'mend of time.' The 'crown of thorns' symbolizes suffering in the skull, and 'Vulcan' (the forger) embodies the '2 years' course,' where forging is 'smithing' and the 'weld of the tire' represents the 'hammer and heat of Orion.' It concludes that myths, read with understanding, reveal parts of a greater whole.

The 'sun man's' journey from 'moon south to polar star north' is explained through the 'entanglement of eight times the cube of 25 letters,' creating '4 quarters of the heavens.' The sun man takes on names like 'Elias' (alias), representing all earthly names. His suffering leads to 'catastrophe' and 'triumph,' with 'hair-breadth escapes.' The 'death of Ham' is linked to 'deadham – Dedham,' and bridge disasters to the 'leap from heaven.' The water tank at Bradford bridge and the engine-driver ('death river') are imbued with symbolic meaning. The 'Ashtabula bridge disaster' serves as a 'forewarning' of 'war N in G.' The 'turnover of Q (D)' is equated with the history of Dover and Andover. The chapter concludes by linking '4 fires in New Hampshire' (Suncook, Lebanon, New Boston, Newton Junction) to the 'junction with heaven earth and hell,' suggesting these events are part of the divine plan.

Explores how syllables predict the future, establishing a connection between 'heaven, earth, and hell.' 'Dumb language' (D you M, mum) of 'sunny mum' (F air) reveals choices for Jews. 'Pioneer' links to 'pi on ear.' 'Ture is true' (TURE as chewer) points to the chew of the Jew. The difference between 'chewer' and 'sure' highlights a 'break at the st,' with S (19th century) and T (20th century) as the 'serpent and cross.' 'Sure' is the 'ruse of the shewer,' revealing the 'shew bread' (O read). Fig. 20 (INRI) symbolizes the '4 rivers of Eden' and the 'X.' The 'two Is' represent the 'pole and the sun in the east.' The chapter concludes that 'earthly adjustment' turns the soul on crosses, reproducing its past life on a 'four-spoke wheel,' where the speaker's voice becomes 'O 4-O,' and physical bodies become 'caterpillars' mixing with dust.

Analyzes the moon's red appearance as blood, representing the 'earth's quarter turn on its axis' and symbolic 'heat.' It states that the moon's turning to blood signifies that it does not provide the 'first day of Aries,' which instead comes from the sun, making the 30th of Pisces the 'last day.' This transition is where the soul is 'thrown out' to 'eat of the Passover Styx.' The '30th day' is the lap from moon to sun, where one 'betrays itself for 30 Pisces (pieces of silver)' and starts a 'cruise.' 'Silver' is linked to 'time and liver,' and '29 Pisces' fit '3 years out of 4,' representing betrayal in the 'leap year.' The chapter connects the 'heal of time' to the 'eater piece' and music, where A at 'concert pitch' requires B natural to be sharpened with G, forming 'the key of H' or 'silent mystery.' The 'one day added for leap year' (29 Pisces) is a 'wise provision from heaven,' with the length of time dead being 'cast out' or 'distance shortened on the orbit,' which is the 'heavenly leap year' where the 'woe man pays the penalty.'

Explores the concept that 'fellow-men say he is sharp,' linking this to 'line accomplishment.' It states that breaking 'high heaven's law' is a greater burden than human law. Man's constant temptation and sinfulness are acknowledged, with 'yield' connecting to 'Y and lied – die L – dial=12.' The chapter asserts that inner thoughts are sins at the 'last day.' 'Paul' is identified as the 'Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John,' representing the 'four seasons' and 'four C son of the divided year = O.' He could 'read the four ways of the trans pyre in G.' 'Theology' is 'th all ogee,' the serpent. 'Prose' is 'P rose from death,' and 'Etymology' is 'eat M all ogee.' 'Rose' links to 'sore,' 'time ore,' 'metal,' 'met all.' 'Ogee' (O G) is the 'foundation of hog,' explaining why hogs absorb snake poison. This affinity of ogee and G is seen as grease blending with grace, triumphing over the sting of death (Pison and Gihon).

Examines 'ascension' as the soul's journey, where O is 'hole of holiness,' and U is the 'silent magnet' controlling life. 'Earn' to 'urn' signifies the 'sweat of the F ace,' and 'sweaty' contains 'A and west,' linking to the cross line. 'Adam earned his bread' means 'ear N H is Q read = dear.' 'Sweat' is 'P her spire, S pire pyre – time fire.' 'Capricornus (Pan)' is letter V with a circle, changeable to B, representing the 'Virgin with the boy in her arms.' This links to 'Saint Thomas’ day – Christmas.' The 'syllable torn' represents the cross, grave, and M (13, the sun's number). The chapter connects 'ascension' to the story of N at A and S of time, and 'Sion' to 'time and eye (9) on,' including the 'Pyrrhic traveller.' The text emphasizes that the body seen after death is the same as before, but the 'four ways of heavenly reading disjoints all of man’s efforts to write the story.'

key_concepts.definition: The underlying, unchanging, and universal divine law that governs all aspects of existence, embedded within language, nature, mythology, and human history. It is revealed through a 'double read' interpretation of all phenomena.

A specific interpretive method that goes beyond the superficial, literal 'face' meaning of language. It involves breaking words into letters and syllables, re-sounding them, applying numerical and symbolic correspondences, and identifying phonetic 'blends' or 'displacements' to uncover the hidden 'Hebraic law' and its deeper, esoteric truths.

Each letter of the alphabet possesses an intrinsic symbolic and numerical value, representing various divine attributes, cosmic forces, astronomical bodies, mythological figures, and aspects of human experience (e.g., A=sun, D=death, E=law, G=holy seventh, M=sun/13, O=circle/God, T=cross, Y=urn/immortality).

The recurring patterns of existence, including human life, death, and spiritual transformation, which are governed by astronomical events and structured by specific numerical cycles (e.g., 20-year periods, 2000-year epochs, 8000-year temples of time). These cycles manifest as repeating historical events and personal experiences.

The celestial framework, composed of zodiacal signs and planetary influences, through which the soul and body undergo processes of 'readjustment,' purification, and transformation. It dictates the 'name story' of individuals and events across different epochs.

A central symbol representing the profound suffering, death, and subsequent spiritual transformation inherent in the human and cosmic cycles. It is not merely a historical event but a recurring pattern within the 'Hebraic law,' often depicted with specific geometric arrangements of 'sticks' or lines.

The ultimate symbol of the profound, hidden knowledge of the 'Hebraic law.' Its pursuit, like Jason's voyage, represents the journey of discovery and spiritual transformation that unveils the universal, underlying truths of existence through cabalistic analysis.

A cabalistic symbol formed by superimposing the letter T (cross) onto P, representing 'Pan' and encompassing a numerical and symbolic framework related to divine law, creation, and specific figures like Judas and Thomas.

The approach of demonstrating that diverse mythological figures (e.g., Jason, Adam, Isaac, Samson, Hercules, Castor, Pollux, Apollo) and biblical characters are all 'the same man' or represent recurring archetypal experiences within the cosmic cycles, interpreted through the lens of 'Jewish Cabalism.'

practical_system.description: The practical system revolves around a rigorous method of 'double reading' any given language to uncover the hidden 'Hebraic law.' This is achieved through an almost cryptographic decomposition and reconstruction of words. The practitioner must meticulously break words down into individual letters and syllables, then 're-sound' them (e.g., 'house' becomes 'H you see,' 'Styx' becomes 'S T y X'), often by adding or subtracting specific 'sticks' (symbolic components of letters) or 'vowels' (H, E, A, V, Y). The analysis involves identifying phonetic 'blends' and 'displacements,' applying the author's extensive lexicon of symbolic letter-meanings (which link letters to numbers, astrological signs, mythological figures, and divine concepts), and tracing how these elements resonate across different words and narratives. The ultimate goal is to see how 'all names in pagan mythology' and biblical stories are 'woven together' to describe the 'cruise' of the soul through cycles of life, death, and transformation, thereby 'extracting Hebrew from any and all languages.'
tools: Any spoken or written language (primarily English, as the medium for extracting Hebrew).
The author's unique system of phonetic and syllabic decomposition and reconstruction.
A set of specific letter-symbolism and numerical correspondences (e.g., A=sun, D=death, E=law, G=holy seventh, M=sun/13, O=circle/God, T=cross, Y=urn).
Geometric diagrams and figures (e.g., Fig. 1-20) representing cosmic structures, time cycles, and letter interactions.
The concept of 'sticks' (as in the components of letters like A, E, H, K, W, Z) that can be added, subtracted, or manipulated.
The 'reed' or 'pen' as a symbolic tool for reading and writing the hidden law.
A method of accentuating specific vowel sounds (O and R) during analysis.
rituals: The 'double reading' or 'reface' interpretation of language, especially by 'spelling by letter and syllable in every conceivable possible displacement,' functions as a meditative or divinatory ritual, aligning the practitioner's mind with the 'Hebraic law.'

The act of 'placing a word on the alter' or 'putting the word text upon the alter' (pages 104, 110, 147) suggests a ceremonial or invocational practice where language is ritually consecrated and analyzed for divine insight.
The specific 'accentuation' of 'oh (O)' and 'ah (R)' during phonetic analysis is a form of vocalic magic, aligning sound with deeper cosmic resonance ('ohah of the sculler').

The study and application of the provided numerical calculations and geometric diagrams (e.g., Fig. 2, Fig. 6, Fig. 7, Fig. 12, Astrological Dial) serve as a form of sacred geometry and numerological contemplation, akin to ceremonial work with sigils or divine names.

relevant_quotes.text: Hebrew is to be extracted from any and all languages of the earth, and can never run out.

Every letter and utterance in language, has a meaning other than man considers as he makes use of the same in the trans-action of business. They all have a high meaning in the great temple of nature, and there they are God's law as revealed to man.
Beneath the face of language lays the Hebraic law, always and forever the same.

After spelling by letters, spell by letter and syllable in every conceivable possible displacement, and always accent the oh (O) and ah, (R) for there is the ohah (oar, ore) of the sculler, the skuller of Golgotha.
All names in pagan mythology are woven together in this work, and herein is found the method of reading the same ac-cording to the Jews of antiquity.

The alphabet being composed of astronomical characters of absolute time meaning, it follows that the story of 4000 years ago would not be the same arrangement of letters as the story of 2000 years ago, because of the difference of the heavenly positions of those letter characters.
In the beginning was the word, and the word was with God, and the word was God.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is a highly idiosyncratic and complex text that aligns with a tradition of linguistic mysticism, reminiscent of some aspects of Jewish Kabbalah (Gematria, Notarikon, Temurah) but applied through an entirely unique and self-devised system. Its relevance lies in offering an alternative, syncretic esoteric cosmology that purports to unify all religious narratives, mythological archetypes, astronomical phenomena, and even the very structure of language under a single 'Hebraic law.' While it lacks academic or mainstream occult validation, its intricate system of letter-symbolism and phonetic deconstruction represents a significant, albeit unconventional, attempt to find a universal, divine code. It reflects a radical form of Hermetic-Qabalistic inquiry, seeking to prove that 'as above, so below' is demonstrably encoded in every word and event.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for 'The Golden Fleece' would be individuals deeply immersed in Western Esotericism, particularly those with a strong interest in linguistic mysticism, Gematria, and comparative mythology who are open to highly unconventional and speculative interpretations. It is for practitioners or researchers who enjoy intricate, self-contained magical systems and are willing to engage in a form of 'operative' textual analysis that demands meticulous attention to phonetic, numerical, and symbolic correspondences beyond established academic or occult frameworks. It is less for beginners and more for those already familiar with esoteric thought who seek unique, personalized avenues of mystical exploration.
